channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Ukrainians in front line regions reel from losses, but say hope dies last for them
item.description: Into their fourth year of war, Ukrainians living in or near front line regions of their country grapple with their losses and contemplate an uncertain future.
item.content:encoded:
Into their fourth year of war, Ukrainians living in or near front line regions of their country grapple with their losses and contemplate an uncertain future.

(Image credit: Claire Harbage)
item.dc:creator: Claire Harbage

item.title: Trump's new tariffs could raise car prices. And, Dems demand answers after Signal leak
item.description: Trump announced he'll impose 25% tariffs on imported cars starting next week. The decision received mixed reactions. And, Democrats are demanding answers after bombing plans were discussed on Signal.
item.content:encoded:
Trump announced he'll impose 25% tariffs on imported cars starting next week. The decision received mixed reactions. And, Democrats are demanding answers after bombing plans were discussed on Signal.

(Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Trump officials downplay the Signal leak. Some military members see a double standard
item.description: The news of the leak of life-and-death operational details to a reporter lands differently with veterans and active-duty troops, who can be prosecuted for much less significant "spillage" incidents.
item.content:encoded:
The news of the leak of life-and-death operational details to a reporter lands differently with veterans and active-duty troops, who can be prosecuted for much less significant "spillage" incidents.

(Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)
item.dc:creator: Quil Lawrence

item.title: March Madness and babies: Are the sounds of the game too big for little ears?
item.description: What's the right age to take kids to a loud sporting event? A Johns Hopkins noise expert on protecting babies' ears and when game day noise might be too much for them.
item.content:encoded:
What's the right age to take kids to a loud sporting event? A Johns Hopkins noise expert on protecting babies' ears and when game day noise might be too much for them.

(Image credit: Jaap Arriens)
item.dc:creator: Barry Gordemer

item.title: Déjà vu all over again? Dodgers are favorites as 2025 MLB season begins
item.description: Major League Baseball's 2025 season gets fully underway Thursday. The scary news for the league: the defending champion Los Angeles Dodgers, favorites to repeat, may be even better this season.
item.content:encoded:
Major League Baseball's 2025 season gets fully underway Thursday. The scary news for the league: the defending champion Los Angeles Dodgers, favorites to repeat, may be even better this season.

(Image credit: John McCoy)
item.dc:creator: Steve Futterman

item.title: A new Utah law is Republicans' latest effort to limit mail ballot return
item.description: Utah's new law is part of a larger effort by Republicans to limit the window in which mail ballots can be counted during an election.
item.content:encoded:
Utah's new law is part of a larger effort by Republicans to limit the window in which mail ballots can be counted during an election.

(Image credit: George Frey)
item.dc:creator: Ashley Lopez

item.title: As Bangladesh gears up for election, a new political player emerges
item.description: Last year, Gen-Z uprising in Bangladesh helped bring down Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. Student activists continue to be central figures in shaping the future of Bangladesh's political landscape.
item.content:encoded:
Last year, Gen-Z uprising in Bangladesh helped bring down Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. Student activists continue to be central figures in shaping the future of Bangladesh's political landscape.

(Image credit: Rajib Dhar)
item.dc:creator: Shamim Chowdhury

item.title: Climate change and overfishing threaten Vietnam's tradition of making fish sauce
item.description: Climate change and overfishing are making it harder to catch the anchovies essential to the condiment that underlies so much of Vietnam and southeast Asia's food.
item.content:encoded:
Climate change and overfishing are making it harder to catch the anchovies essential to the condiment that underlies so much of Vietnam and southeast Asia's food.

(Image credit: Yannick Peterhans)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Exhibit takes visitors inside the annex where Anne Frank lived
item.description: For the first time, a re-creation of the annex where Anne Frank and her family hid is available outside of Amsterdam. Visitors in New York said its themes reverberated in today's political climate.
item.content:encoded:
For the first time, a re-creation of the annex where Anne Frank and her family hid is available outside of Amsterdam. Visitors in New York said its themes reverberated in today's political climate.

(Image credit: John Halpern)
item.dc:creator: Sarah Ventre

item.title: As U.S. foreign aid grants get slashed, Greenland gets money for a dog race
item.description: Second lady Usha Vance has scrapped a plan to attend Greenland's national dog sled race this week. But American tax dollars will help support the race anyway.
item.content:encoded:
Second lady Usha Vance has scrapped a plan to attend Greenland's national dog sled race this week. But American tax dollars will help support the race anyway.

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
item.dc:creator: Tom Bowman
